channel.title: BBC News - Home
channel.description: The latest stories from the Home section of the BBC News web site.
channel.copyright: Copyright: (C) British Broadcasting Corporation, see http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/help/rss/4498287.stm for terms and conditions of reuse.

item.title: Syria rebels to get 'urgent support'
item.description: Ministers from the Friends of Syria group of nations meeting in Qatar agree to provide "urgent" support to rebels fighting President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: US seeks Snowden's HK extradition
item.description: The White House contacts Hong Kong for the extradition of US intelligence fugitive Edward Snowden, who leaked details of secret surveillance.

item.title: UK economy 'leaving intensive care'
item.description: The UK economy is "leaving intensive care", Chancellor George Osborne will say as he unveils his spending plans for 2015-16 on Wednesday.

item.title: Turkey rivals hold mass rallies
item.description: Mass rallies are held in Turkey by the government and its opponents, with police again clearing Istanbul's Taksim Square of protesters.

item.title: Kerry cautious on Taliban talks
item.description: US Secretary of State John Kerry expresses caution about future talks with the Taliban, following a row over the Afghan insurgents' office in Qatar.

item.title: India flood rescue efforts intensify
item.description: Efforts are stepped up in northern India to rescue tens of thousands of people trapped by floods that have already killed nearly 600 people.

item.title: Ferry 'holed' as it strikes dock
item.description: Almost 500 passengers are stranded for more than two hours on a ferry after it hits the quay while docking in Harwich and takes on water.

item.title: Danish driver killed in Le Mans race
item.description: Danish driver Allan Simonsen dies after a crash in the Le Mans endurance race in France, the first death at the event since 1997.

item.title: Obama promises US climate plan
item.description: US President Barack Obama promises to outline his plan to deal with climate change in a speech at Georgetown University on Tuesday.

item.title: Deadly attack on Iraq Shia mosque
item.description: A suicide bomber kills at least 14 people at a Shia mosque north of the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, after three other attacks leave nine dead.

item.title: Gaza singer wins Arab Idol contest
item.description: Celebrations erupt across the Palestinian territories at news that a wedding singer from the Gaza Strip has won the Arab Idol talent show.

item.title: Roads shut down for car-free Sunday
item.description: Roads in part of Bristol city centre close for the mayor's car-free Sundays initiative which he hopes will Make Sunday Special.

item.title: 'Supermoon' lights up night sky
item.description: The night sky is illuminated by what appears to be a much bigger and brighter Moon - a so-called "supermoon".

item.title: 'Our wives' Naval toast rewritten
item.description: A traditional toast made at Royal Navy mess dinners on Saturday nights has been updated to reflect cultural changes, the Ministry of Defence says.

item.title: Italy 2-4 Brazil
item.description: Neymar scores his third goal of the Confederations Cup as Brazil qualify top of Group A after beating Italy.

item.title: Australia captain Horwill cited
item.description: Australia captain James Horwill is cited after an incident with Alun Wyn Jones in the first Test with the Lions.

item.title: Ascot winner Thomas Chippendale dies
item.description: Hardwicke Stakes-winning horse Thomas Chippendale dies of a suspected heart attack shortly after victory at Royal Ascot.

item.title: Lions job half done - Warburton
item.description: Lions captain Sam Warburton says his side have to improve to claim a Test series victory against Australia.

item.title: Champions Trophy final: Can England topple India?
item.description: BBC Sport assesses England's chances of a maiden 50-over title against India in Sunday's Champions Trophy final

item.title: Town centres 'missing out on retail'
item.description: Research suggests the government's new planning rules are doing little to coax local authorities into locating big new retail developments in town centres.

item.title: Markets stable after sharp falls
item.description: Markets regain ground during US afternoon trading, following 48 hours of falls prompted by comments from the US Federal Reserve.

item.title: Miliband rules out more borrowing
item.description: Labour would not increase borrowing to reverse cuts in government spending, Ed Miliband says as he warns the party must be "credible".

item.title: Unions warn of anti-cuts action
item.description: Trade union leaders promise co-ordinated industrial action in response to government spending cuts as thousands of campaigners gather in central London.

item.title: Hunt: 'Action if CQC cover-up found'
item.description: Health secretary Jeremy Hunt, has said there should be "very, very serious consequences" for anyone found guilty of a cover-up at England's Care Quality Commission.

item.title: 'Big fall' in excess diabetes deaths
item.description: The extra risk of dying for people with diabetes has fallen sharply since the mid-1990s, a study suggests.

item.title: Infant classes over 30 almost treble
item.description: The number of four-to-seven-year-olds being taught in classes of more than 30 pupils has almost trebled in five years, according to official data.

item.title: Private school 'isolation' warning
item.description: Independent schools have a moral obligation to work with state schools, says England's chief inspector of schools.

item.title: Google given 35 days to delete data
item.description: Google has been given 35 days to delete wi-fi data "mistakenly collected" in 2010, or face criminal proceedings.

item.title: Premier League starts piracy swoop
item.description: The Premier League has written to internet service providers to signal its intent to have a popular football streaming site blocked.

item.title: Buzz Aldrin calls for a Mars colony
item.description: The second man to walk on the moon believes more manned missions are needed to the Red Planet.

item.title: Plants 'seen doing quantum physics'
item.description: Researchers pin down the contentious notion that ideas from the strange world of quantum mechanics underpin plants' skill at harvesting sunlight.

item.title: Andrea Begley wins The Voice final
item.description: Northern Irish singer Andrea Begley wins the final of this year's series of The Voice on BBC One, triumphing over bookmakers' favourite Leah McFall.

item.title: Gandolfini died after heart attack
item.description: The Sopranos star James Gandolfini died following a heart attack, an autopsy confirms.

item.title: How often do abusive teacher-pupil relationships occur?
item.description: Teacher Jeremy Forrest has been found guilty of abducting a schoolgirl and taking her to France. But how often do abusive relationships occur?

item.title: 10 things festivals have given us
item.description: Flowery tents, the onesies and gin in a bag, what else has the music festival given us?

item.title: Shot artist 'may not paint again'
item.description: The wife of a war artist who was shot by a Taliban sniper in Afghanistan fears he may not be able to paint again.

item.title: Cornflake chaos set Kellogg's ablaze
item.description: A blaze erupts on the fifth floor of the Kellogg's factory in Greater Manchester when cornflakes get jammed in a oven.

item.title: Elite cyclists in Glasgow city race
item.description: About 20,000 people are expected to line the streets of Glasgow city centre to watch cycling stars such as Mark Cavendish and Laura Trott.

item.title: China air link 'vital for Scotland'
item.description: A direct air link between China and Scotland could be "instrumental" in increasing Scotland's trade and tourism, a committee of MSPs has said.

item.title: SF minister hurt after march protest
item.description: Sinn Fein Culture Minister Carál Ní Chuilín is injured in an incident involving a police Land Rover, after a contentious Orange march in Belfast.

item.title: Teenager beaten with hammers in city
item.description: A 19-year-old man is taken to hospital after being beaten with hammers by a gang of men in Belfast.

item.title: Protests over limit of two bin bags
item.description: Residents in Monmouthshire are to be limited to two bin bags of rubbish a fortnight - the strictest in Wales - to make them recycle more.

item.title: Road blocked in university staff row
item.description: A road crossing demonstration closes the entrance to a university campus in support of two staff members who protesters claim were suspended.

item.title: Nelson Mandela ambulance broke down
item.description: The ambulance carrying Nelson Mandela to hospital two weeks ago broke down and he had to be transferred to another, the presidency says.

item.title: Mozambique 'ex-rebels behind raids'
item.description: At least two people are killed in three attacks suspected to be carried out by fighters of the opposition Renamo party in Mozambique, the government says.

item.title: Singapore mulls legal action on smog
item.description: Singapore says it is exploring whether to charge two Singapore-based companies in connection with severe smog triggered by forest fires in Indonesia.

item.title: Australia 21-23 British and Irish Lions
item.description: The British and Irish Lions ride their luck to clinch a narrow victory over Australia in a riveting first Test match in Brisbane.

item.title: Human rights group evicted in Moscow
item.description: A prominent Russian human rights group is forcibly evicted from its office in Moscow after a stand-off with the city authorities.

item.title: Tour winner Ullrich admits doping
item.description: Former Tour de France winner Jan Ullrich confesses to doping and being treated by disgraced Spanish doctor Eufemiano Fuentes.

item.title: Brazil clashes despite Rousseff plea
item.description: Clashes take place in the Brazilian cities of Salvador and Belo Horizonte despite President Rousseff's attempt to respond to protesters' demands.

item.title: Protest over Bolivian jail closure
item.description: Inmates at Bolivia's biggest prison say they are protesting against government plans to close the jail after allegations that a girl was raped there.

item.title: Couple die of thirst in Saudi desert
item.description: A husband and wife die of thirst after losing their way in Saudi Arabia's vast southern desert, known as the Empty Quarter.

item.title: Mass rally for Egyptian president
item.description: Thousands of people take to the streets in Egypt in a show of support for President Mohammed Morsi, as opposition pressure grows.

item.title: Two die in wing walker crash in Ohio
item.description: A wing walker and her pilot are killed when their biplane crashes during an air show near Dayton in the US state of Ohio.

item.title: Deadly floods hit western Canada
item.description: At least three people have died as floods sweep western Canada and officials order the evacuation of Calgary's city centre as waters rise.

item.title: In pictures: Yoko Ono's Meltdown
item.description: Annual event of music and the visual arts

item.title: Week in pictures: 15-21 June 2013
item.description: Photos from around the world this week

item.title: In pictures: Refugee children in Lebanon
item.description: Moises Saman's photos from Lebanon

item.title: Day in pictures: 20 June 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: : 20 June

item.title: In pictures: Brazil protests
item.description: Demonstrations continue around the country

item.title: Restored crystal grotto unveiled
item.description: An 18th Century crystal grotto in Surrey

item.title: Day in pictures: 19 June 2013
item.description: Twenty-four hours of news photos: 19 June 2013

item.title: In pictures: Brazil protest banners
item.description: Mass protests in Brazil

item.title: VIDEO: House of Commons
item.description: The prime minister updates MPs on the recent summit of the G8 group of nations.

item.title: VIDEO: The moment Andrea won The Voice
item.description: Andrea Begley has won the BBC singing competition The Voice, beating bookies' favourite Leah McFall, as well as fellow finalists Mike Ward and Matt Henry.

item.title: VIDEO: Jon Stewart 'captured' on Egypt TV
item.description: The American political satirist Jon Stewart has appeared as a guest on Egypt's top satirical TV show El Bernameg hosted by Bassem Youssef, which is modelled after his own programme "The Daily Show."

item.title: VIDEO: Is Nepal losing its best porters?
item.description: Trekking agencies in Nepal say they are struggling to find enough experienced porters to help carry tourists' equipment and provide advice about ascending the area's peaks.

item.title: VIDEO: F1 'like 12 rounds with Carl Froch'
item.description: In Formula 1 racing, lightning reflexes and the ability to handle vehicles at speeds of more than 170 mph are a given, but drivers also need concentration, fitness and strength.

item.title: VIDEO: Would you use a 'glove phone'?
item.description: Designer Sean Miles explains how he tackled the challenge of creating 'glove phones', using recycled mobile handsets.

item.title: VIDEO: Roof collides with bridge in Canada
item.description: Amateur footage has captured the moment a roof collided with a bridge as it was washed down stream in Bragg Creek, Alberta.

item.title: VIDEO: Battle to save India floods stranded
item.description: Rescuers in northern India are desperately trying to reach thousands of people stranded in remote mountain areas following flash floods and landslides.

item.title: VIDEO: Why is Singapore choking in a haze?
item.description: Pollution levels reached a new record high for a third day in a row in Singapore, as smoky haze from fires in Indonesia shrouded the city state.

item.title: Victory is everything for Lions
item.description: BBC Sport's Bryn Palmer says fortune favoured the Lions

item.title: Your pictures: Flight
item.description: Readers' photos on the theme of flight.

item.title: Posh toilets, private butlers and plenty of bubbles
item.description: An inside look into a day at Royal Ascot 2013

item.title: How long is the runway in Fast & Furious 6?
item.description: The action blockbuster that is going to need a longer runway

item.title: From blind audition to dancing blind on live TV
item.description: The challenges blind performers face on TV

item.title: Most mysterious book 'meaningful'
item.description: Trying to crack the 'world's most mysterious book'

item.title: 10 things we didn't know last week
item.description: Dad dancing makes the OED and other nuggets

item.title: Can coins cause allergies?
item.description: The allergy risk lurking in your change

item.title: Room for growth: Viagra patent ends
item.description: Fergus Walsh on the ending of Viagra's patent

item.title: China: credit crunch or worse?
item.description: Is the Chinese economy heading for a fall?
